poem:
Title: "To Scribble the Unheard"

In '03, Bates put ink to plight,
Hoped the gentle Post might light,
Upon the eyes of those in flight,
In tower high, obscured from sight. 

"Can't conjure will from paper thin,
Nor hearts unseal that sit within,
But in silence lies a sin,
For unread letters breed chagrin."

His call in script, lost in the din.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Campaigner Alan Bates says Post Office caused ‘harm and injustice’ as he appears at Horizon inquiry – UK politics live 12.04pm BST Alan Bates is saying that he hoped a letter about his circumstances in August 2003 would have been read by senior leaders at the organisation. He said “I can’t do more than draw their attention to it. I can’t force them to read it, but if you don’t write to them, then they’ll". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
